title: Massive Airport Computer Outage Led to Bad Morning for American, JetBlue, Alaska Airlines Flyers
description: Airports across the country had computer outages due to Sabre's "system issue", which assists American, JetBlue, and Alaska Airlines.

(Photo by Gary Hershorn/Getty Images)  Gary Hershorn Corbis via Getty Images        By Laura Stampler  3:54 PM EDT       Even TSA pre-check couldn‚Äôt help flyers avoid massive lines and delays at airports across the U.S. Tuesday morning due to a major‚Äîalbeit temporary‚Äîcomputer outage impacting JetBlue, American, and Alaska Airlines that left passengers and gate attendants alike unable to check into flights and access online information.  Sabre, a Texas-based tech company that provides support to the aforementioned airlines, took responsibility and apologized for the since-resolved technological glitch in an early afternoon tweet , noting it ‚Äúexperienced a system issue that impacted some customers.‚Äù  Although the company didn‚Äôt specify the cause of the malfunction, or how long it lasted, some airlines began fielding customers‚Äô concerned tweets about being unable to access the companies‚Äô websites beginning around 9 a.m. ET.  But the issue appeared to really come to a head two hours later, when a larger volume of passengers noted that they were unable to board their flights due to a system crash. Pictures from Boston Logan Airport to Seattle‚Äôs SeaTac Airport to Fort Lauderdale showed crowds of passengers and agents alike having difficulty checking in. Can‚Äôt check in at kiosk either. Been waiting in line with many others and not getting any updates. Check-in isn‚Äôt moving and gate agents are asking if ‚ÄúANYONE‚Äù has a paper boarding pas.  ‚Äî Eric Robinson (@emikerob) March 26, 2019       Sabre, which didn‚Äôt immediately respond to Fortune‚Äôs request for comment, acknowledged the issue in an 11:56 a.m. tweet , although Newsweek  reports that the problem had already been resolved for some airlines by then.  ‚ÄúTechnical teams were immediately engaged,‚Äù Sabre tweeted an hour later. ‚ÄúSystems have recovered and customers are reporting normal operations. We apologize for the inconvenience to those affected.‚Äù  Individual airlines were quick to note that the issue was with an outside source‚Äôs system.  ‚ÄúEarlier today, Sabre had a brief technical issue that impacted multiple carriers, including American Airlines ,‚Äù an airline spokesperson told Fortune via email. ‚ÄúThis technical issue has been resolved. We apologize to our customers for the inconvenience.‚Äù  JetBlue also apologized to those who were impacted by the technical problem, telling Fortune , ‚ÄúAll functions have been restored following a temporary outage of Sabre‚Äôs systems that impacted multiple airlines.‚Äù  Sabre doesn‚Äôt exclusively work with airlines.  In 2016, the company made headlines due to a massive data breach of its hotel reservation system‚Äî serving 32,000 properties including Trump Hotels‚Äîthat compromised consumers‚Äô credit card numbers and security codes.
